author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: More Red Carpet Looks From the Vanity Fair Party
description: Stars including Kylie Jenner, Vanessa Hudgens and Emma Stone let their personalities shine through their gowns at the post-awards show bash.
content: If the Oscars red carpet has increasingly become the effective style ego of the fashion/Hollywood marketing machine,  then the after-party attire has become its id: a moment for experimentation, self-expression and risk-taking. With fewer cameras involved, the environment is more about pleasure than business, and the clothes are too. That makes them even more enjoyable to ogle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Pamela Anderson Still Isn’t Wearing Makeup
description: A new campaign for the denim brand Re/Done shows the actress in the barefaced look she has embraced in Hollywood and at fashion week.
content: Pamela Anderson has done some “life-ing” as she calls it. No longer strictly an object of adolescent fantasies, she has become a seasoned version of the girl next door — albeit with a lot more oomph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Moves to Crack Down on TikTok
description: Also, uproar about a retouched royal photo and an Oscars recap.
content: House Republicans plan to vote this week on legislation that would force the Chinese owners of TikTok to divest or be barred in the U.S., even after Donald Trump came out strongly against banning the platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick and Olivia Bensimon
title: ‘Bling Bishop’ Who Boasted of Ties to Eric Adams Is Convicted of Fraud
description: Lamor Whitehead was accused of using $90,000 of a parishioner’s retirement savings to buy luxury goods and trying to force a businessman to lend him $500,000.
content: Lamor Whitehead, a Brooklyn preacher known as the “bling bishop” for his flashy luxury possessions, was convicted in Manhattan federal court on Monday of defrauding a parishioner and trying to extort a businessman while boasting about his ties to Mayor Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Oscar Glory for ‘Oppenheimer’ Rewards Studio Chief’s Vision
description: Under Donna Langley’s leadership, Universal has managed the rare feat of achieving creative dominance and commercial supremacy at the same time.
content: “Queen!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Jimmy Kimmel Jabbed Back at Donald Trump During the Oscars
description: Yes, that was a real post by the former president.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump couldn’t help himself. And Jimmy Kimmel couldn’t resist either. So the Oscars wound to a close on a political note.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Emma Stone Wins Her Second Best Actress Oscar for ‘Poor Things’
description: Stone, who portrayed Bella Baxter in the Yorgos Lanthimos-directed film, was visibly overwhelmed in her acceptance speech.
content: Last year’s Oscar for best actress went to a universe-hopping laundromat owner who at one point appears to have hot dogs for fingers. Naturally, this year had to go even stranger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Biden Has a Ways to Go on That Manufacturing Renaissance
description: His boosterism about factory jobs is backed by policy, but not yet strong results.
content: In his State of the Union address last Thursday, President Biden said, “Where is it written that we can’t be the manufacturing capital of the world? We are. We will.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 11, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 11, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: In Death Penalty Cases, a Texas Court Tests the Supreme Court’s Patience
description: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, one law professor said, treats Supreme Court rulings as “optional guideposts rather than the commands of a higher tribunal.”
content: After a Texas prosecutor’s extraordinary concession that his office had used false evidence to secure a death sentence, the Supreme Court told a Texas appeals court last year to have another look at the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Borges
title: A Multitasker’s Guide to Regaining Focus
description: We can’t really do more than one thing at a time, experts say. But these tactics can help.
content: Multitasking is just the way many of us live. How often do you text while stuck in traffic, lose track of a podcast while doing chores, or flutter between the news and your inbox?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Ira von Fürstenberg, Jet-Setting Princess and Actress, Dies at 83
description: With her aristocratic lineage, high-profile husbands and famous friends, she embodied a chic life of luxury as an international social figure.
content: Ira von Fürstenberg, who came as close as one can get to having it all as an Italian-born princess descended from Charlemagne, an heiress to the Fiat fortune, a Vogue model, a big-screen ingénue and a globe-trotting bon vivant, died on Feb. 19 at her home in Rome. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Swiss Rescuers Find Bodies of Five Missing Skiers
description: The police said weather conditions had deteriorated after the group set out from the town of Zermatt over the weekend. The search continued for a sixth person.
content: Five missing skiers were found dead in the Swiss Alps and the search was ongoing for a sixth member of their group, the local police said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Liset Cruz
title: Graffiti With Swastikas and Racist Rant Rattles a New York High School
description: The police said the vandalism found in a boys’ bathroom at Beacon High School in Manhattan was being investigated as a potential hate crime.
content: The images were disturbing: Three large red swastikas. A menacing warning that read, “I HATE BLACKS.” And a graphic threat of a school shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Why Democrats Are Hopeful in North Carolina and Nervous in Georgia
description: President Biden’s campaign and its allies are targeting both battlegrounds — but only one state has a highly controversial Republican nominee lower on the ballot.
content: Democrats are starting to dream that President Biden can wrench North Carolina away from Donald J. Trump in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: One of New York’s ‘Worst Landlords’ Faces Arrest Over Building Neglect
description: In a rare step, the city’s housing department asked the court to issue an arrest warrant for the landlord, Daniel Ohebshalom.
content: A New York City landlord could face jail time in connection with “dangerous conditions” at two of his Manhattan apartment buildings, the city announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fernanda Eberstadt
title: A Love Affair Bridges a Social Divide That Politics Can’t
description: Nicolas Mathieu’s novel “Connemara” illuminates a clash of values and visions in contemporary France.
content: Anglophone readers seeking a broader view of France than the Paris of bourgeois intellectuals have had plenty to read in recent years. Novelists as varied as Marie NDiaye, Annie Ernaux and Édouard Louis have introduced us to the hard-bitten northern regions of their youths, to the hinterlands of shuttered factories, to derelict city centers and suburbs whose inhabitants, after years of voting Communist, are turning to the anti-immigrant right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: A ‘Roméo et Juliette’ Is Saved by Its Stars
description: Bartlett Sher’s middling production returned to the Metropolitan Opera, with a glorious Benjamin Bernheim and Nadine Sierra in the title roles.
content: Sometimes you just need a few great singers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Could Trump Save TikTok?
description: The former president targeted the platform while in office, but has now come out against a bill that could ban the short video app in the U.S.
content: TikTok users have continued to flood the social media platform — and lawmakers’ inboxes — with pleas to halt a bill that would force its Chinese owners to divest or face a ban in the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Navigating Israeli Restrictions, Many Palestinians Find It Hard to Reach Al Aqsa
description: Muslim access to the mosque compound has long been a point of contention as Israel has exerted tighter control.
content: As the sermon about the Muslim holy month of Ramadan sounded over the speakers from Al Aqsa Mosque, 13-year-old Yousef al-Sideeq sat on a bench outside the compound’s gates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson
title: Torn Between Golden Past and Thorny Present, Oscars Still Had Some Fun
description: Even as the telecast indulged in the usual jokes, references to the 2023 strikes and current wars had their place, in our critics’ view.
content: Last year may have been the year of “Barbenheimer,” but this year’s Academy Awards will henceforth be known as the “Oppenbarbie” Oscars. There was plenty of bubble-gum pink to go around, but the 96th Academy Awards effectively belonged to Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer,” his magisterial biographical portrait of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the so-called father of the atomic bomb. The Times’s chief film critic, Manohla Dargis, and its movie critic, Alissa Wilkinson, discuss the show, the awards, the snubs, the jeers and, yes, even movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: The Promise of the PCOS Diet Falls Apart
description: Patients were told for years that cutting calories would ease the symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome. But research suggests dieting may not help at all.
content: For years, people who had polycystic ovary syndrome and were also overweight were told that their symptoms would improve if they lost weight via a restrictive diet. In 2018, a leading group of PCOS experts recommended that overweight or obese women with the hormonal disorder consider reducing their caloric intake by up to 750 calories a day. That guidance helped to spawn questionable diet programs on social media, and reinforced an impression among people with PCOS that if only they could successfully alter their diets, they would feel better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Trezza
title: With an Orange-Tufted Spiderhunter, Birder Breaks Record for Sightings
description: In February, Peter Kaestner beat out the competition to document his 10,000th bird species.
content: On Feb. 9, Peter Kaestner stood in the shadow of majestic Tinuy-an Falls on the Philippine island of Mindanao, on the cusp of a record he’d spent seven decades chasing and worried that he’d arrived too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: 27 Works of Fiction Coming This Spring
description: Stories by Amor Towles, a sequel to Colm Toibin’s “Brooklyn,” a new thriller by Tana French and more.
content: In her second novel, Gonzalez, a Pulitzer Prize finalist and the author of “Olga Dies Dreaming,” traces the dual narrative of Anita de Monte — a 1980s Cuban American performance artist who fell to her death from her husband’s apartment building — and Raquel, a 1990s art history student who sees parallels between Anita’s life and her own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: colossal
description: This word has appeared in 217 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word colossal has appeared in 217 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 7 in “Rome’s Ancient Grandeur Towers Anew With a Copy of a Colossus” by Elisabetta Povoledo:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: The British Royal Family: A Timeline of the Last Few Months
description: It’s been a busy few months for King Charles III and his family. There have been surgeries, health announcements, and one family photograph people can’t stop talking about.
content: For months, nearly all eyes have been fixated on the ebbs and flows of the British royal family, with King Charles III and Catherine, the Princess of Wales, in the spotlight because of health matters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: U.S. Pledges Another $130 Million to Restore Order to Haiti
description: The U.S. secretary of state announced more aid for the multinational security mission planned to deploy to Haiti, as well as more humanitarian aid.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken announced Monday that the United States would provide an additional $100 million in aid toward a United Nations-backed multinational security mission planned to deploy to Haiti, which has been overrun by gang violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: California’s Economy Has Been Pinched by Unemployment
description: The Golden State’s jobless rate remains stubbornly high.
content: Tech layoffs. Hollywood strikes. Rural joblessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Conor Dougherty, Rikki Novetsky, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Will Reid, Marc Georges, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: The Billionaires’ Secret Plan to Solve California’s Housing Crisis
description: A company has spent hundreds of millions of dollars buying land in the Bay Area in the hopes of building a new city.
content: For years, a mysterious company has been buying farmland on the outskirts of Silicon Valley, eventually putting together a plot twice the size of San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.2 Million Homes in California
description: A three-bedroom house in Glendale, a Craftsman bungalow in San Francisco and a two-bedroom condominium in a gated retirement community in Carmel.
content: This recently updated house is on a sloping street in the Woodbury neighborhood, about a five-minute drive from public elementary, middle and high schools, and 10 minutes from the Americana at Brand shopping center and the Glendale Galleria mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: U.S. Judge Blocks Rule Extending Reach of Labor Law to Franchisers
description: The ruling upends the National Labor Relations Board’s move to broaden the standard for determining when a company is liable for labor law violations.
content: A federal judge, siding with business lobbying groups, has blocked a rule that would broaden the reach of federal labor law to make big franchisers like McDonald’s responsible for the conditions of workers they have not directly hired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: On the Wild Intoxications of Spring
description: My happiness is twofold. Spring is here! But also: Thank God it didn’t come too terribly early this year.
content: I spied the first spring beauty of the year on Feb. 20, the same week a Northern flicker started drumming on our metal chimney, the week of budburst for our red maple sapling and our young red mulberries. At our house, these are the most reliable harbingers of spring: pink-pollened flowers in the leaf litter, a woodpecker signaling his territory to a potential mate, sap rising in branches still low enough to watch their buds burst into bloom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: He Was in Prison. She Was in Covid Lockdown. They Freed Each Other.
description: During the pandemic Jessica Jacobs binge-watched true crime shows. Inspired, she started working on cases with a lawyer. Two men who spent decades behind bars walked free.
content: Four years ago, as a deadly virus began to upend the world, Jessica Jacobs was at home in Los Angeles, in a wooded canyon that has long attracted bohemian types, and like many Americans was binge-watching true crime documentaries on Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Ryan Gosling Delivers a ‘Just Ken’ Spectacle at the Oscars
description: In one of the evening’s most anticipated performances, Gosling and dozens of dancers went over the top and even brought out Slash for a cameo on guitar.
content: In one of the most anticipated and surely one of the most exuberant moments of Oscar night, Ryan Gosling took the stage to perform “I’m Just Ken,” the nominated song from “Barbie” by Mark Ronson and Andrew Wyatt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s Budget Underscores Divide With Republicans and Trump
description: The president’s $7.3 trillion budget proposal for the next fiscal year includes about $3 trillion in deficit reduction over a decade, largely from raising taxes on high earners and corporations.
content: President Biden proposed a $7.3 trillion budget on Monday packed with tax increases on corporations and high earners, new spending on social programs and a wide range of efforts to combat high consumer costs like housing and college tuition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Oscars’ In Memoriam Segment Honors Aleksei Navalny, Among Film Greats
description: Before paying tribute to the industry figures who died in the past year, a clip of the Russian opposition leader played as an introduction to the segment.
content: The in memoriam segment at the Academy Awards opened not with a Hollywood star, but with a clip of Aleksei A. Navalny from “Navalny,” the Oscar-winning 2022 documentary about the Russian opposition leader who died last month in a Russian prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Malachy McCourt, Actor, Memoirist and Gadabout, Dies at 92
description: Playing the professional Irishman, he returned from Limerick to New York where he tended bar and appeared in soap operas and, with his family, scattered “Angela’s Ashes.”
content: Malachy McCourt, who fled a melancholic childhood in Ireland for America, where he applied his blarney and brogue to become something of a professional Irishman as a thespian, a barkeep and a best-selling memoirist, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump’s Biden Mockery Upsets People Who Stutter: ‘We’ve Heard This Before’
description: The former president mimicked his rival while at a rally over the weekend. For those who stutter, his remark “hits that familiar humiliation feeling.”
content: Róisín McManus has stuttered her whole life. When she saw the video start to circulate of former President Donald J. Trump at a rally on Saturday imitating President Biden stuttering, she had two competing reactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: How the Wait for Olympic Medals Became an Endurance Sport
description: Doping rules, legal challenges and endless appeals have left some medalists waiting (and waiting) for their golds.
content: It took Lashinda Demus of the United States 52.77 seconds to run the women’s 400-meter hurdles at the 2012 London Olympics. It took more than a decade for her to be upgraded to first place from second. A year after that decision, and 12 years after the race, she is still waiting to receive her gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Sex Trafficking, De Facto Lies and Immigration
description: Senator Katie Britt’s deeply misleading tale.
content: On Thursday, Katie Britt, the junior senator from Alabama, delivered the Republican response to the State of the Union address. Her overwrought performance has been widely mocked; that’s OK for late-night TV, but I’m not going to join in that chorus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Jonathan Swan
title: House to Move Ahead With Bill Targeting TikTok as Trump Flips to Oppose It
description: With both parties eager to demonstrate a willingness to be tough on China, bipartisan legislation to force the Chinese owners of the platform to divest or face a ban was moving forward.
content: House Republican leaders are moving this week to pass legislation that would force the Chinese owners of TikTok to sell the platform or face being barred in the United States, even after former President Donald J. Trump came out against targeting the popular social media app he once vowed to ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Balazs Gardi
title: How the A.I. That Drives ChatGPT Will Move Into the Physical World
description: Covariant, a robotics start-up, is designing technology that lets robots learn skills much like chatbots do.
content: Companies like OpenAI and Midjourney build chatbots, image generators and other artificial intelligence tools that operate in the digital world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Pantry-Friendly Persian Lentil Rice With Dates
description: More weeknight dishes that wow: herby pork larb, sticky chicken with brussels sprouts and shrimp in purgatory.
content: I became a regular at Sofreh the minute Nasim Alikhani first flung open the doors to the chic Persian restaurant in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. I was irresistibly pulled in by her fragrant platters of duck fesenjan and fish with herbs and tamarind. No matter my order, though, I had to include adas polo ba khorma — Medjool date and lentil rice. A cinnamon-scented mound of soft basmati rice, lentils and dates sprinkled with saffron and rose water and garnished with crisp slivers of fried onion, it was the dish that most haunted me between visits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Lauren Leatherby
title: Princess Catherine Apologizes, Saying She Edited Image
description: A Mother’s Day portrait of Catherine, Princess of Wales, with her three children shows a range of anomalies indicating it had been digitally altered.
content: Catherine, the Princess of Wales, apologized on Monday for doctoring a photo of her with her three children, which was recalled by several news agencies on Sunday after they determined the image had been manipulated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Al Pacino Explains Awkward Oscars Moment Presenting Best Picture
description: The star, whose abrupt announcement that “Oppenheimer” had won best picture took some viewers by surprise, said the show’s producers had asked him not to name the other nominees.
content: The actor Al Pacino sought to explain his awkward and abrupt announcement of “Oppenheimer” as the best picture winner at the Academy Awards, saying in a statement on Monday that the producers had decided he would not read the full list of nominees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ariel Kaminer
title: ‘Oppenheimer,’ My Uncle and the Secrets America Still Doesn’t Like to Tell
description: The Oscar-winning film centers on one man’s remarkable history. My uncle’s life tells a very different story about the fallout of the atomic bomb.
content: The darkened sky stretches over miles of desert sand as in the distance, from an illuminated scaffold, the object rises that will change the world. The first atomic test is the defining scene in “Oppenheimer,” which won seven Academy Awards on Sunday night, including best picture. The scene plays out over seven or so minutes of steadily escalating tension: No one knew whether the bomb would go off at all that night and, if it did, whether it would incinerate the whole world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Klein
title: Democrats Need to Stop Playing Nice
description: Too often, Democrats litigate; Republicans fight.
content: There is a moment in the 2008 HBO movie “Recount” that illuminates an essential difference between Republicans and Democrats. The film was a fictionalized account of the mayhem that followed the 2000 presidential election in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Wait, Were Those Shoulder Straps Floating?
description: A sculptural element on Emily Blunt and Florence Pugh raised some eyebrows.
content: Emily Blunt showed up to the Academy Awards, arm in arm with her husband, the actor John Krasinski, while her dress rejected the premise: Her straps refused to touch her arms. The neckline floated, as if it had been lifted from her Oscar-nominated shoulders by invisible fingers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Ukraine Could Deploy F-16s as Soon as July, but Only a Few
description: Countries promised the fighter jets last year, but delivering them and training pilots have proved complex. Ukraine may start with as few as six, out of about 45 pledged.
content: The jets are ready, and the flight instructors are waiting, at a new training center in Romania that was created to teach Ukraine’s pilots to fly the F-16 warplane. But there’s a catch: The Ukrainian pilots have yet to arrive, despite declarations last summer that the center would play a crucial role in getting them into the air to defend their country from increasingly deadly Russian strikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: With Pride and Hope, Ukraine Celebrates Oscar Win for Mariupol Documentary
description: Ukrainians say recognition for “20 Days in Mariupol” will help debunk Russian propaganda and refocus attention on the situation in Russian-occupied territories.
content: Streets and squares are being changed from Ukrainian names to those from the Soviet era. Only Russian passport holders will have access to health care and social services. Teachers have been forced to switch to Russian curriculums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Shin
title: A New Era for the Golden Mall
description: Once the pre-eminent food court in Flushing, Queens, for a variety of regional Chinese cuisines, this mall has reopened after a four-year renovation. And a new Golden Mall in Manhattan is on the horizon.
content: When the Golden Mall opened in Flushing, Queens, in 1990, its patrons didn’t mind getting lost within the maze of vendors in order to find chile oil-slicked noodles, chunky sea bass dumplings or cumin-scented lamb burgers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland and Arvind Dilawar
title: A Showcase for Israeli Property Creates Rancor in a Diverse Town
description: A synagogue in Teaneck, N.J., hosted a show promoting real estate in Israel. Pro-Palestinian groups organized angry demonstrations outside.
content: Hundreds of demonstrators protested on Sunday outside an Orthodox Jewish synagogue in Teaneck, N.J., where 35 Israeli real estate companies were promoting their properties to potential American buyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: ‘My Eyes See “Oppenheimer”’: Al Pacino’s Awkward Best Picture Announcement
description: Pacino did not name the 10 nominees before saying the prize went to “Oppenheimer,” the favorite to win.
content: Al Pacino put a room full of Hollywood stars a little bit on edge to close out the 96th Academy Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Testimony Fleshes Out Account of Trump’s Demand to Go to Capitol on Jan. 6
description: But a newly released transcript of an interview of the Secret Service agent who drove Donald Trump’s vehicle that day disputes that he tried to grab the steering wheel or lunged at another agent.
content: President Donald J. Trump had just delivered his fiery speech at the Ellipse early on the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, setting in motion the attack by his supporters on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Shaw
title: Why the Supreme Court Should Clear the Way for a Pre-election Trump Trial
description: In the Jan. 6 case, when the court decides will be as important as what it decides.
content: When the U.S. Supreme Court ruled last week that Colorado could not keep Donald Trump off its presidential primary ballot, it proved at least one thing: The court can decide a case both quickly and with a keen eye to the political calendar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Calls for Higher Taxes on Corporations and the Wealthy
description: The budget, which would cut the deficit by $3 trillion over the next decade, reinforces Biden’s efforts to counter Republican tax proposals that Democrats deride as giveaways to the wealthy.
content: The budget that President Biden released on Monday projects to cut deficits by $3 trillion over a decade, and it does so with an approach that has become familiar: tax increases for companies and the wealthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Confronted by an Angry Moose? Here’s What to Do.
description: Moose are ordinarily docile animals. The chances of having to defend yourself against one in the wild are slim, but not zero.
content: Moose, the largest member of the deer family, are probably most closely associated in popular culture with the dimwitted but well-meaning cartoon character Bullwinkle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2024 Oscars
description: In a fairly even-keeled night, emotions still ran high, whether it was the rush of “I’m Just Ken” or heartfelt words from Rita Moreno to America Ferrera.
content: Fittingly for an Academy Awards celebrating 2023, the year of “Barbenheimer,” the movies that made up that phenomenon commanded our attention on Sunday night, too. None of it was a surprise, exactly — we knew Ryan Gosling was going to perform the song “I’m Just Ken,” from “Barbie.” And “Oppenheimer” had been the ceremony’s front-runner since awards season started last fall. Still, we weren’t prepared for just how much the ceremony, which for the most part ran smoothly, would get a boost from those twin blockbusters. Here are the highs and lows as we saw them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: You Haven’t Seen Blue Until You’ve Seen San Andres
description: The island, close to Nicaragua but part of Colombia, boasts waters in seven shades of the color. Counting them — from a boat, from a cay, from the shade of a coconut tree — is a meditative experience.
content: On San Andres, a small Colombian island in an archipelago off the Caribbean coast of Nicaragua, counting the blues in the famous “Sea of Seven Colors” is on every visitor’s to-do list. It’s a midday activity done en route as you cruise among the cays, or keys, dotting San Andres’s eastern side: low-lying (mostly) uninhabited specks that aren’t much more than coral topped with palm trees and circled by sandbars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Fourth Anniversary of the Covid Pandemic
description: And where things stand today.
content: Four years ago today, society began to shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: U. of Texas at Austin Will Return to Standardized Test Requirement
description: The university said SAT and ACT scores help it place students in programs that fit them best.
content: The University of Texas at Austin said Monday that it would again require standardized tests for admissions, becoming the latest selective university to reinstate requirements for SAT or ACT scores that were abandoned during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Republicans Threaten to Ban TikTok, Despite Trump’s Dissent
description: Also, Biden proposed new taxes and larger social programs. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: House Republican leaders said today that they were planning to vote this week on legislation demanding that the video app TikTok cuts ties with its Chinese parent company or face a ban in the U.S. Lawmakers in both parties have described the app as a national security threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Ukrainian Director Says He’d Rather Have No Oscar and No War
description: ‘20 Days in Mariupol,’ Mstyslav Chernov’s harrowing first-person account from the early days of Russia’s invasion, won for best documentary feature.
content: The Ukrainian director Mstyslav Chernov used his acceptance speech for “20 Days in Mariupol,” which won the Oscar for best documentary feature on Sunday, to give an emotional denunciation of the continued invasion of his country by Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
title: For Trump, a Blizzard of Court Action Is Just Another Monday
description: A lawyer for E. Jean Carroll suggested she could sue the former president again, and his lawyers filed a last-ditch request to delay his upcoming Manhattan criminal trial.
content: For anyone but Donald J. Trump, Monday’s legal docket would have induced dizziness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Wegovy Moves Beyond Weight Loss
description: The F.D.A. has approved a new use for heart health that will fuel even more demand for the drug.
content: Wegovy, the blockbuster weight loss drug, is now approved for a new use: reducing the risk of heart attacks, strokes and cardiovascular-related death in adults who have heart disease and are overweight or have obesity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Legal Settlement Clarifies Reach of Florida’s ‘Don’t Say Gay’ Law
description: The law will stay on the books, but the settlement makes clear it that does not ban classroom references to L.G.B.T.Q. people, including in literature and class discussions.
content: ​The State of Florida and plaintiffs who challenged a parental rights law that critics nicknamed “Don’t Say Gay” agreed to a settlement on Monday that clarifies the reach of the legislation, which prohibits instruction on sexual orientation and gender identity in kindergarten through eighth grade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Menendez Is Arraigned for the Third Time in 6 Months
description: “Once again — not guilty,” Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, said. His wife, Nadine Menendez, also pleaded not guilty.
content: For the third time in six months, Senator Robert Menendez stood before a judge in Manhattan on Monday to be formally arraigned on charges in an expansive federal bribery case. He pleaded not guilty, just as he had twice before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saeed Al-Batati, Eric Schmitt and Vivian Nereim
title: Al Qaeda’s Yemen Branch Says Its Leader Has Died
description: The group, whose power and reach have diminished in recent years, did not give a cause of death for Khaled Batarfi, who once fought alongside the Taliban.
content: The Yemen-based branch of Al Qaeda said on Sunday that its leader, Khaled Batarfi, had died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Surprise: An ‘Extraterrestrial’ Gadget Was Something More Familiar
description: In 2014 a fireball from outer space was posited to be an alien artifact. A recent study suggests otherwise.
content: In January of 2014, a meteor fell from space off the coast of Papua New Guinea. That might have been the end of it, but several years later Avi Loeb, a theoretical astrophysicist at Harvard, drew on seismic data from near the site, looked for crash remains on the ocean floor and proposed that the remains “may reflect an extraterrestrial technological origin.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What’s the Best — and Worst — Part of Being a Sports Fan?
description: A guest essayist asks why we remain fans when sports most often leads to heartbreak? What keeps you rooting?
content: Are you a sports fan? Do you live and die with the fortunes of your favorite players or teams?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan, Nicole Sperling and Sinna Nasseri
title: Inside the Governors Ball 2024 Oscars Party
description: Emma Stone and Christopher Nolan were among the winners celebrating at the official after-party of the Academy Awards.
content: At the Governors Ball after the Oscars on Sunday evening, the writer-director Christopher Nolan and the producer Emma Thomas stepped off a raised dais after having their multiple Oscars engraved and were greeted by the party’s chef, Wolfgang Puck. In honor of the night’s biggest prizewinners, Puck was serving a selection of British food: Roast beef with Yorkshire pudding and fish and chips were presented to the couple, who were both delighted by a taste of home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T.M. Brown
title: When Canceling Your Reservation Costs as Much as Dinner
description: Fed up with no-shows and last-minute cancellations, restaurants are increasingly charging fees as high as $100 a head. And some diners are pushing back.
content: To celebrate his wife’s birthday in 2022, Brian Azara, a mechanical engineer in New York City, booked a table for two at a Michelin-starred restaurant in Brooklyn. But when their son was suddenly hospitalized with severe asthma, Mr. Azara had to cancel the reservation. A few minutes later, he checked his credit card account and saw a $200 fee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: The Woman Who Tried to Make Porn Safe for Feminism
description: How the archive of Candida Royalle, a porn star turned pioneering director, landed at Harvard — and inspired a new book challenging the conventional history of the sexual revolution.
content: Harvard’s Schlesinger Library is the nation’s leading repository for women’s history, home to the papers of suffragists and social reformers, poets and politicians, the collective behind “Our Bodies, Ourselves” and iconic figures like Amelia Earhart, Angela Davis and Julia Child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alla Katsnelson
title: When Cicadas Emerge, Things Might Get a Little Wet
description: A new study reveals that cicadas can discharge urine with far more force than their size would suggest. This spring’s  output could be significant.
content: This spring, when the ground temperature hits 64 degrees Fahrenheit, trillions of cicadas will dig their way up from beneath the soil across the Southern and Midwestern United States. In a rare so-called double emergence, two distinct cicada broods — one on a 13-year life cycle and the other on a 17-year one — will take to the trees to sing, eat and mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Biden and Netanyahu at Odds Over Gaza, and Catherine’s Palace Photo Fans Rumors
description: Plus, highlights from last night’s Oscars
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Deadspin Sells to European Media Company, Leaving Staff Behind
description: The new owner, Lineup Publishing, will not be bringing on any of the sports website’s existing staff members.
content: Deadspin, the sports news website, has been sold to a European digital media company, its owner, G/O Media, said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Overdose or Poisoning? A New Debate Over What to Call a Drug Death.
description: Grieving families want official records and popular discourse to move away from reflexive use of “overdose,” which they believe blames victims for their deaths.
content: The death certificate for Ryan Bagwell, a 19-year-old from Mission, Texas, states that he died from a fentanyl overdose.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Gang Uprising Is Aggravating Crisis in Haiti
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 11, 2024.
content: “I ask myself what happened to this generation. Are they even human?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: An Old Trick to the Crispiest Tofu
description: Why fry when you can freeze?
content: About 1,500 years ago, in the mountains of northern China, you might have found bamboo mats lined with slabs of tofu, resting in the snow overnight. Once frozen solid, “the structure and basic character of the tofu underwent a radical transformation,” William Shurtleff and Akiko Aoyagi wrote in “The Book of Tofu” (1975).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: A new generation of abortion voters
description: Plus: Trump flips on a TikTok ban.
content: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June 2022, it created shock waves that reverberated through American politics, helping Democrats stave off a Republican rout in the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Dead Outlaw’ Review: Not Much of a Bandit, but What a Corpse
description: The creators of “The Band’s Visit” return with this mischievous ghost story of a musical based on an odd slice of Old West history.
content: In the final chapter of Elmer McCurdy’s macabre posthumous journey through the American West, his red-painted corpse dangled from a noose inside a Southern California amusement park ride: a creepy bit of décor to spook the thrill seekers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: And the Award for Best Performance at the State of the Union Goes to …
description: Did Biden change anyone’s mind? And can he maintain the momentum?
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I think it’s safe to say that Joe Biden’s confident performance at the State of the Union has put to rest any doubts that he’ll be the Democratic nominee, with Kamala Harris as his running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hard
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ and 55th N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards
description: The 20th season of this medical drama airs on ABC. And CBS hosts the annual awards show honoring excellence in film and television.
content: For TV viewers like me who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network shows, movies and specials broadcasting Monday through Sunday, March 11-16. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: American Man Sentenced to Life After Killing Woman at German Castle
description: The U.S. citizen attacked two women, also Americans, near Germany’s iconic Neuschwanstein Castle, and attempted to push both of them to their deaths, a court found. One was killed, the other survived.
content: A German court on Monday convicted an American man of raping and murdering a woman and attempting to murder her companion near the Neuschwanstein Castle, one of the country’s most famous tourist destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Even Photoshop Can’t Erase Royals’ Latest P.R. Blemish
description: A Mother’s Day photo was meant to douse speculation about the Princess of Wales’ health. It did the opposite — and threatened to undermine trust in the royal family.
content: If a picture is worth a thousand words, then a digitally altered picture of an absent British princess is apparently worth a million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: What’s So Funny About a Naked Man?
description: John Cena’s skit at the Academy Awards underscores an intractable gender imbalance, even as it gets legitimate laughs.
content: John Cena’s ‘streaker manqué’ routine at the Oscars was pretty funny. In an obvious setup, host Jimmy Kimmel asked, “Can you imagine if a nude man ran across the stage today?” upon which a seemingly undressed Mr. Cena popped his head out from behind the curtain to say, “I changed my mind, I don’t want to do the streaker bit.” When Mr. Kimmel reminded him that it was all for comedy, Mr. Cena replied with faux seriousness, “the male body is not a joke.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Biden Marks Ramadan, Saying the War Has Inflicted ‘Terrible Suffering’ on Gaza
description: The president said he would press for a cease-fire and more aid for Gaza, and noted that many American Muslims were grieving for family members killed there.
content: President Biden, marking the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, said he would press for a cease-fire in Gaza and more humanitarian aid for the territory, and noted that many American Muslims were grieving for family members killed there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Morgan Wallen, With Latest No. 1, Tops a Garth Brooks Record
description: Wallen’s “One Thing at a Time” notches its 19th week atop the all-genre Billboard 200 chart a year after its release.
content: Morgan Wallen’s “One Thing at a Time” was already a chart monster. The album, released last March, spent its first 12 weeks at No. 1, then notched another four by the fall, and two more early this year. Thanks to consistently huge streaming numbers, it was the most popular album of 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Trump Mentions Cutting Entitlements, and Biden Pounces
description: Donald Trump’s campaign said he “will continue to strongly protect Social Security and Medicare in his second term,” clarifying more ambiguous comments in a CNBC interview.
content: After former President Donald J. Trump appeared to suggest he was open to cutting federal entitlement programs such as Social Security and Medicare, President Biden immediately seized on the comments, saying, “Not on my watch.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: Biden and Netanyahu clash over Gaza.
content: President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel traded criticisms as a public dispute over Israel’s tactics in Gaza heated up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Harris and RF. Alvarez
title: Missing the Gay Best Friend
description: In film and on TV, he was a sign of cultural progress. Then he was a tired stereotype. Then he disappeared. So why do we want him back?
content: SOMETIMES, YOU DON’T know how much you’ve been missing something, or even that you’ve been missing it, until you have it back. That may explain the unexpected nostalgic pang I felt while watching Nathan Lane connive and conspire with an array of imperiously behatted women on the second season of Max’s real housewives of New York costume drama “The Gilded Age.” Or the similar pang I felt while watching Mario Cantone reprise his role as the embittered confidant Anthony Marentino on the second season of Max’s other real housewives of New York costume drama “And Just Like That …” In both instances, it seemed suddenly clear that, for a long time now, popular culture has been moving forward without a once-essential style accessory: the Gay Best Friend. We’re not supposed to mourn his absence; we’re not supposed to want him back. But I kind of do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Tiny Stamp That May Sell for Millions
description: The “Z-grill” is likely to go for the highest price ever paid for a U.S. stamp when it is auctioned in June.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll find out why a 1-cent postage stamp could become the most expensive U.S. stamp ever sold. We’ll also get details on Gov. Kathy Hochul’s order forbidding National Guard soldiers to carry long guns when they are on duty in the subway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Coming Soon to Manhattan, a Brand-New Tiny Forest
description: Pocket-size forests filled with native plants have been embraced worldwide for their environmental benefits. Now one is planned for New York City.
content: A trend that’s gaining momentum around the world is set to finally arrive in Manhattan. It’s a tiny forest, to be planted on the southern end of Roosevelt Island, in the East River, this spring. According to its creators, it would be the first of its kind in the city and would consist of 1,000 native plants, trees and shrubs, covering just 2,700 square feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Netanyahu’s Coalition ‘May Be in Jeopardy,’ Intelligence Report Says
description: The document predicted that Israel would struggle to achieve its goal of destroying Hamas in Gaza.
content: A new American intelligence assessment released on Monday raised doubts about whether Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel could stay in power, as the C.I.A. director said a hostage deal was the most practical way to halt, at least temporarily, the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Mihir Zaveri
title: To Fix a Housing Crisis, New York Leaders Seek to Revive a 1950s Idea
description: State Democrats are set to propose a series of ideas to address affordability and a lack of new homes. Some of the ideas are new. And some are very, very old.
content: To address a growing housing crisis, leaders in New York’s State Senate are set to propose sweeping legislation on Monday that would encourage new construction, establish new tenant protections and also revive some older ideas for building affordable housing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Larissa Anderson, Daniel Powell and Alissa Wilkinson
title: Oscar Highlights: The Good, the Ken and the Naked
description: Our movie critic looks back on the Academy Awards.
content: The 96th Academy Awards were held Sunday in Los Angeles. Our movie critic Alissa Wilkinson says that, between the comedy bits, the musical performances and a few significant wins, there was more than enough to keep an audience engaged. In this episode, Alissa reflects on the show and whether this year’s Oscars will live on in popular memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Kim Kardashian, Sydney Sweeney and Serena Williams at the Vanity Fair Oscars Party
description: The magazine welcomed the famous (and the fame-adjacent) while toasting itself for hosting the extravaganza 30 times over the years.
content: “This is made of success — not everyone can have it,” the actress and comedian Tiffany Haddish said Sunday night, as she held the train on her dress and danced her way through the crowd inside the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Beverly Hills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Huck Finn’ Is a Masterpiece. This Retelling Just Might Be, Too.
description: Percival Everett’s new novel amends Mark Twain’s classic tale with the enslaved sidekick, Jim, at its center.
content: “Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,” the critic Lionel Trilling wrote, is “one of the world’s great books and one of the central documents of American culture,” in part because it grows with its readers. Mark Twain’s 1884 novel is a catapulting adventure story when one is 10, but its amplitude is grasped only in adulthood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Cillian Murphy: Get to Know the New Oscar Winner’s Work
description: “Oppenheimer” wasn’t the first time he’s played a physicist. In “Sunshine,” “28 Days Later” and more, you can get a sense of just how wide his range is.
content: The first thing you notice about Cillian Murphy is his eyes. As a young filmgoer, I clocked them in the historical drama “Girl With a Pearl Earring” (2003), when he was romancing Scarlett Johansson. But over the years I came to find myself more and more taken by the rarity of Murphy’s transmutable talent as he tackled everything from horror movies to comic-book fare to war pictures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: 3 Children and 2 Adults Killed as School Bus and Truck Collide in Illinois
description: All four people in the bus died, as did the driver of a semi-truck, the authorities. The school district canceled classes on Tuesday and Wednesday out of respect for the victims.
content: Five people, including three young children, were killed on Monday morning when a school bus collided with a semi-truck on an Illinois roadway, setting both vehicles ablaze, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Automakers Are Sharing Consumers’ Driving Behavior With Insurance Companies
description: LexisNexis, which generates consumer risk profiles for the insurers, knew about every trip G.M. drivers had taken in their cars, including when they sped, braked too hard or accelerated rapidly.
content: Kenn Dahl says he has always been a careful driver. The owner of a software company near Seattle, he drives a leased Chevrolet Bolt. He’s never been responsible for an accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Natasha Frost
title: ‘Strong Movement’ on Flight to New Zealand Leaves Dozens Injured
description: The airline, Latam, said a “technical problem” had caused the incident. Most of the injuries were minor, but one person was in serious condition.
content: About 50 people were treated by emergency medical workers on Monday after a Latam Airlines flight bound for Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, experienced what the airline called “strong movement” caused by a “technical problem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: Where to Stream 2024 Oscar Winners, From ‘Oppenheimer’ to ‘Poor Things’
description: Most of the night’s winners can be watched at home. Here’s a guide to help you find the honorees.
content: For the second year in a row, following “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” a single film dominated the Oscars with seven awards as “Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s imposing portrait of the architect of the atomic bomb, took picture and director, and picked up nods for two of its stars, Cillian Murphy and Robert Downey Jr. Subscribers to Peacock can currently stream the film, but it’s an affordable rent on all the major platforms. With the exception of the visual effects wonder “Godzilla Minus One” and the two animated films, Hayao Miyazaki’s feature “The Boy and the Heron” and the short “War Is Over! Inspired by the Work of John and Yoko,” all of the other Oscar winners are accessible through either streaming services or the usual outlets. With war as a major theme throughout the ceremony, it’s worth noting that “20 Years in Mariupol,” the documentary winner about the Russian siege on the Ukrainian city, is currently available for free on Frontline PBS’s YouTube page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: My Children Helped Me Remember How to Fly
description: The best present I have ever received is that my grown children still want to play with me.
content: “Want us to teach you how to fly?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: Adrianne Lenker Isn’t Scared of Sadness
description: The Big Thief singer and songwriter’s new solo album, “Bright Future,” is a model for staying soft, and open, in an often cruel world.
content: When the singer and songwriter Adrianne Lenker was 21, she was involved in a bike accident that knocked out one of her incisors. For a while, she walked around with a fake, gold-colored cap in her mouth. But after she was able to invest in a porcelain tooth, Lenker realized she actually didn’t want to forget about the injury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Why Does Ramadan Start at Different Times in Different Places?
description: The exact start date of Islam’s holiest month depends on when local Islamic authorities declare the sighting of the new moon.
content: Ramadan, the holiest month of the Muslim calendar, starts on Monday in some countries but on Tuesday in others. How is that possible?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Fudge Steps Down as Housing Secretary
description: Marcia Fudge, who has led the Department of Housing and Urban Development since the early days of the Biden administration, announced her resignation, citing family concerns.
content: Marcia L. Fudge, the secretary of housing and urban development, announced on Monday that she would resign this month after three years of presiding over seismic shifts in the housing market brought on by the Covid-19 pandemic and changes in the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Cillian Murphy Wins His First Oscar, Best Actor for ‘Oppenheimer’
description: Murphy, who was nominated for the first time, portrayed the physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer in the Christopher Nolan film.
content: Cillian Murphy won the Oscar for best actor for his portrayal in “Oppenheimer” of the physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, who developed the atomic bomb and was haunted by its impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: For This Rookie Judge, a Pivotal Decision Looms in the Georgia Trump Case
description: Judge Scott McAfee will soon decide whether to disqualify Fani Willis, the prosecutor leading the case, on the grounds that her romance with a subordinate created a conflict of interest.
content: For Judge Scott McAfee, it was probably an awkward moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl and Dean Kaufman
title: A New York Loft Where the Art Comes First
description: In designing their Manhattan home, a couple took cues from their wide-ranging collection.
content: IN THE 1960S and ’70s, clearing out and refinishing a downtown loft was a rite of passage for New York artists, who were drawn by cheap rent and ample studio space to the postindustrial buildings of SoHo and TriBeCa. Today, of course, those same addresses are luxury real estate, but the loft hasn’t lost its appeal in the art world. The difference: Potential buyers are now more likely to be seeking ideal places in which to display art, not create it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cody Delistraty
title: 17 Works of Nonfiction Coming This Spring
description: Memoirs from Brittney Griner and Salman Rushdie, a look at pioneering Black ballerinas, a new historical account from Erik Larson — and plenty more.
content: Though this isn’t the drag queen and TV personality’s first memoir, it’s arguably RuPaul’s most revealing. Excavating questions of childhood love, a reckoning with his challenging father and the power found in thinking more expansively about gender (especially as a “feminine Black man, in violation of society’s norms by virtue of just existing,” as he writes), “The House of Hidden Meanings” is a powerful coming-of-age of a prominent queer icon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 19 Looks That Did the Most at the Oscars
description: The red carpet at the Academy Awards had elegant, over-the-top and even political fashion. These were the best (and the not-so-best) outfits.
content: At the 96th Academy Awards on Sunday, the red carpet showed not only its true color but also its reputation as a vehicle for elegant, over-the-top and even political fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sinna Nasseri
title: Our Favorite Photos From the Oscars Red Carpet
description: An array of stars turned up the wattage, including Emma Stone and Billie Eilish and Oscar newcomers like Colman Domingo and Danielle Brooks.
content: The 96th Academy Awards bowed on Sunday with a return to tradition: The red carpet was, well, red. A year after Hollywood’s stars made their way across a champagne-colored rug, and several months after work stoppages led by actors’ and writers’ unions came to an end, they were greeted once again by the familiar décor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: A Dutch Quandary Offers a Glimpse of a Deepening Problem for Europe
description: The ascent of Geert Wilders has vexed parties struggling with how to work with a far-right leader too popular to shun. It’s a puzzle bigger than the Netherlands.
content: Just months ago, Geert Wilders was an anathema to most Dutch political parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Scientists Discover 100 New Marine Species in New Zealand
description: The findings, from the largely uncharted waters of Bounty Trough, show that “we’ve got a long way to go in terms of understanding where life is found in the ocean,” a researcher said.
content: A team of 21 scientists set off on an expedition in the largely uncharted waters of Bounty Trough off the coast of the South Island of New Zealand in February hoping to find a trove of new species.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: ‘What Was I Made For?’ Wins Billie Eilish (and ‘Barbie’) an Oscar
description: The song, which Eilish wrote with her brother, Finneas O’Connell, is the siblings’ second award in the category.
content: Billie Eilish’s tender, yearning ballad “What Was I Made For?” won for original song, ensuring that “Barbie” will leave the ceremony with at least one Oscar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden Pushes Lower Health Care Costs and Takes a Dig at Trump
description: Speaking in New Hampshire, the president highlighted his pledges to cap insulin prices, make permanent expanded tax credits under the Affordable Care Act and limit out-of-pocket prescription drug costs.
content: President Biden visited New Hampshire on Monday to talk up proposals in his newly released budget that he said would reduce health care costs for Americans, part of a general-election push to lay out his vision for a second term and convince voters of the success of his first one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elise Young
title: How Much Access to Government Records Does the Public Deserve?
description: Proposed restrictions in New Jersey are pitting municipal and county officials against supporters of government transparency.
content: Less than a year ago, the governor of New Jersey, Philip D. Murphy, signed legislation that weakened the power of a watchdog agency set up to police election campaigns. Now, lawmakers are moving to limit another good-government effort, a public records law established to limit corruption by encouraging government transparency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arash Azizi
title: Change Is Coming to Iran, Just Not the Change We Hoped For
description: The next generation of the country’s leaders want authority, not theocracy.
content: On March 1, Iranians went to the polls for the first time since the protest movement of 2022 and the war in Gaza. The vote, for the Parliament and Assembly of Experts, which appoints the supreme leader, was far from a referendum on current leaders, though. The big result was the number of people who didn’t vote. Even if we are to believe official numbers, the turnout of this election marks the lowest since the Islamic Revolution of 1979: only 41 percent of Iranian voters showed up at the polls.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Challenges of Teaching Constitutional Law Today
description: Readers discuss an Opinion piece about a politicized Supreme Court. Also: Trump’s mockery of Biden; fans of the president; alcoholism; great literature.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Jonathan Glazer Condemns ‘Occupation’ and Violence in Israel and Gaza
description: Glazer, the director of “The Zone of Interest,” spoke about the war while accepting the Oscar for best international feature.
content: The Israel-Hamas war was prominently addressed on the Oscars stage on Sunday in an acceptance speech for “The Zone of Interest,” which follows the domestic life of a Nazi commandant whose house is just outside the Auschwitz concentration camp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: NYC Restaurant Sheds Are Here to Stay. Here Are the New Guidelines.
description: The city’s Department of Transportation issued new rules for Dining Out NYC, its official program, and more food news.
content: Like them or not, the outdoor dining sheds that have been an upshot of the pandemic are more or less here to stay. Last week, City Hall and the Department of Transportation issued new guidelines for Dining Out NYC, its official program, and the largest such program in the country. “It’s been a priority for Mayor Adams from Day 1,” said Ya-Ting Liu, the city’s chief public realm officer. Restaurants and other establishments that serve food can now apply for permits to take part through an official portal online. Those that are approved and pay a fee for a four-year license ($1,050) for either a roadbed or sidewalk enclosure have 30 days to remove their temporary structures or outfit them to comply with the city’s rules. The authorized structures can remain in place from April through Nov. 29. Restaurants without approval will have to remove their sheds by Aug. 3; those with a pending application will have until Nov. 1. The city has approved four prototypes designed by WXY Studio to eliminate many of the problems with existing makeshift sheds and to adapt to various roadway and sidewalk configurations. They are being built by SITU, a fabrication company, and are already in place at several restaurants. They are not heated and will supposedly be rat-proof; some models are equipped with solar panels. At Bodrum, on Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side, Huseyin Ozer, an owner, said the 40-foot unit in the roadway outside his restaurant had planters, could be customized with signage, will allow for 16 seats and is easy to disassemble. Hinged floor panels lift to allow for cleaning. Full compliance citywide is expected when the season reopens in April 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cassel
title: Chaotic Scene Outside Al Aqsa Mosque Before Start of Ramadan
description: Israeli police clashed with worshipers outside of Al Aqsa mosque as many attempted to enter the complex for Ramadan prayers. After being denied entry due to their age, some younger men prayed outside of the holy site.
